awd_titl_txt: IRES TRACK I: THE GLOBAL INSTITUTE FOR CARBON-HYDROGEN FUNCTIONALIZATION (GICHF)
awd_abstract_narration:
Center for Selective Carbon - Hydrogen (C-H) Functionalization (CCHF) will coordinate and support a highly collaborative international exchange program with sites in Japan, South Korea and Germany. During the exchanges, students will participate in collaborative projects directed towards developing new approaches to making molecules in a streamlined and sustainable way. These new approaches will have impact on modern medicine and manufacturing, including drug discovery and materials science. This proposal builds upon a previous NSF Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) program and provides the exciting opportunity to capitalize on the collaborative bonds already established to grow a truly diverse and globally prepared next generation of scientists that benefit from an integrated and successful global research collective. The overarching scientific theme that brings these international teams together is C-H functionalization, a science that is at the leading edge of academic chemical research.

The aim of this International Research Experiences for Students (IRES) proposal is to establish a vibrant training environment for collaborative global research in the general field of C?H functionalization. This will be achieved by means of a productive international research collaborative, the Global Institute for C-H Functionalization (GICHF).  This program will involve student exchanges and collaborations between the CCHF and three major international centers in the general field of C-H functionalization.  These centers are the World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI)-funded Institute for Transformative Bio-Molecule (WPI-ITbM) at Nagoya University, Japan, the Institutes for Basic Sciences-funded Center for Catalytic Hydrocarbon Functionalizations (IBS-CF) at KAIST, South Korea, and the Photocatalysis Center based at the University of Regensburg, Germany.  Each year a cohort of CCHF students, consisting of 3 graduate and 5 undergraduate students will perform 8-12 week exchanges between May-August with the international partners. The CCHF will also host international students, funded by the international partners, to ensure reciprocity in the collaborative exchanges.  Programming throughout the year will be in place to prepare the students for the research exchanges and to ensure they make the most of these experiences. The experience will include a GICHF annual meeting, which will be hosted, on a rotating basis, at one of our international partners. The annual meeting will serve as an opportunity to bring together the entire student cohort as well as faculty from the United States, for a week-long brainstorming, community building, and educational event with our international partners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
C-H Functionalization has the potential to change the way practitioners of synthetic organic chemistry construct molecules. As a science that enables and supports many other fields, streamlining the synthesis of organic molecules in a sustainable and inexpensive fashion has a broad and meaningful impact across society. In recognition of this potential a number of research organizations focused on C-H functionalization have been established across the globe.

The NSF established the Center for Chemical Innovation on Selective C-H Functionalization (CCHF), which consisted of 25 faculty from 15 universities working together in close connection with several industrial partners, to bring C-H functionalization into the main stream of the logic of organic synthesis and  to accelerate its impact in material science and the pharmaceutical industry. Recognizing the presence of  high profile international centers, the CCHF applied for funding for an International Research Exchange for Students (IRES), with the aim of creating a global network of researchers, focusing on C-H functionalization. Since receiving this award, the CCHF has established the Global Institute for Carbon-Hydrogen Functionalization (GICHF), a collective of researchers and organizations whose complimentary expertise provide a vibrant and exciting forum for collaboration. The core partners in this enterprise have been:

  • The Institute for Transformative Bio-Molecules (ITbM), based at Nagoya University, Japan. Funded by the World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI-RCI), it is focused on the application of C-H Functionalization to the synthesis of molecules that precisely control biotic function and production in plants and the development of novel bio-imaging molecules.
  • The Center for Catalytic Hydrocarbon Functionalization (IBS-CCHF), based at KAIST, South Korea. Funded by the Institutes for Basic Science (IBS), it is focused on the controlled functionalization of petroleum and biomass chemical feedstock chemicals and the catalytic de-functionalization of more complex bio-feedstock (such as cellulose).

Around this core triad we also built an extended network of expertise, engaging with specialists at the University of Regensburg, Germany (immobilized catalysts and flow reactor design) and the Centre for Rapid Online Analysis of Reactions at Imperial College, UK.

The intent of this program is to have students involved in exciting collaborative research with our international partners by spending 3 months immersed in doing research in another country. The program gave the students great exposure to other cultures, while also, ensuring that they were involved in a highly significant international collaborative research study. The highlight for the students was the brain-storming work-shop in Korea where all our students came together with our international partners to share their research accomplishments and to explore new directions for collaboration. The first year was a highly successful in-person experience in which a cohort of 9 students studied abroad, but due to the challenges of international travel caused by Covid-19, the subsequent engagement needed to be adjusted to virtual rather than in-person.   Despite these challenges, good connections between the CCHF and the international partners were maintained, which has led to beneficial experiences for our students and a number of high impact collaborative publications. During this exchange program, the CCHF has been collaborating with the best international centers in the field of C-H functionalization, and these connections remain strong, even after completion of the IRES program.
